title: Bølling oscillation
text:
The Bølling oscillation, also Bølling interstadial, was a cool temperate climatic <a href="interstadial">interstadial</a> between the glacial <a href="Oldest%20Dryas">Oldest Dryas</a> and <a href="Older%20Dryas">Older Dryas</a> <a href="stadial">stadial</a>s, between 14,700 and 14,100 <a href="Before%20Present">BP</a>, near to the end of the <a href="last%20glacial%20period">last glacial period</a>. It is named after a peat sequence discovered at <a href="B%C3%B8lling%20lake">Bølling lake</a> in central <a href="Jutland">Jutland</a>, <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>. It is used to describe a period of time in relation to <a href="Pollen%20zone">Pollen zone</a> Ib—in regions where the Older Dryas is not detected in climatological evidence, the <a href="B%C3%B8lling%E2%80%93Aller%C3%B8d">Bølling–Allerød</a> is considered a single interstadial period.
Dates.
The beginning of the Bølling is also the high-resolution date for the sharp temperature rise marking the end of the Oldest Dryas at 14,670 <a href="Before%20Present">BP</a>. Roberts (1998) uses 15,000. A range of 14,650–14,000 BP calibrated has been assigned to the Bølling layer of the excavation at Lake <a href="Neuch%C3%A2tel">Neuchâtel</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, 1992–1993. The Oxygen isotope record from <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> ice includes the Bølling warm peak between 14,600 and 14,100 BP. Most of the recent dates available fall within a few hundred years of these.
Flora.
Of the two periods, Bølling and <a href="Aller%C3%B8d%20Oscillation">Allerød</a>, Bølling is the warmer and came on more suddenly. During it sea level rose about 35 m due to glacial melt. Ice uncovered large parts of north Europe and temperate forests covered Europe from 29 deg. to 41 deg. north <a href="latitude">latitude</a>. After some pioneer vegetation, such as "<a href="Salix%20polaris">Salix polaris</a>" and "<a href="Dryas%20octopetala">Dryas octopetala</a>", hardwoods, such as "<a href="Quercus">Quercus</a>", and softwoods, "<a href="Betula">Betula</a>" and "<a href="Pinus">Pinus</a>", spread northward for a brief few hundred years.
Fauna.
During this time late <a href="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a> animals spread northward from refugia in the three peninsulas, Spain, Italy and the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a>. Geneticists can identify the general location by studying degrees of consanguinity in the modern animals of Europe. The hunting camps of ancient humans remain a major source of <a href="fauna%20%28animals%29">faunal</a> <a href="fossil">fossil</a>s.
Animals hunted by humans are predominantly the big-game mammals: <a href="reindeer">reindeer</a>, <a href="horse">horse</a>, <a href="saiga">saiga</a>, <a href="antelope">antelope</a>, <a href="bison">bison</a>, <a href="woolly%20mammoth">woolly mammoth</a> and <a href="woolly%20rhinoceros">woolly rhinoceros</a>. In the alpine regions <a href="ibex">ibex</a> and <a href="chamois">chamois</a> were hunted. Throughout the forest were <a href="red%20deer">red deer</a>. Smaller animals, such as <a href="fox">fox</a>, <a href="wolf">wolf</a>, <a href="hare">hare</a> and <a href="squirrel">squirrel</a> also appear. <a href="Salmon">Salmon</a> was fished. For more details, see also the references to fauna under <a href="Oldest%20Dryas">Oldest Dryas</a> and <a href="Older%20Dryas">Older Dryas</a>.
Human cultures.
Humans reentered the forests of Europe in search of big game, which they were beginning to hunt relentlessly, many to extinction. Their cultures were the last of the Late Upper <a href="Palaeolithic">Palaeolithic</a>. <a href="Magdalenian">Magdalenian</a> hunters moved up the <a href="Loire">Loire</a> into the <a href="Paris%20Basin">Paris Basin</a>. In the drainage basin of the <a href="Dordogne">Dordogne</a>, the <a href="Perigordian">Perigordian</a> prevailed. The <a href="Epigravettian">Epigravettian</a> dominated Italy. In the north, the <a href="Hamburgian">Hamburgian</a>, <a href="Creswellian">Creswellian</a> and <a href="Federmesser">Federmesser</a> cultures are found. In the middle east, the pre-agricultural <a href="Natufian">Natufian</a> settled around the east coast of the Mediterranean to exploit wild cereals, such as <a href="emmer">emmer</a> and two-row <a href="barley">barley</a>. In the Allerød they would begin to domesticate these plants.
